part_1_2019_discovery.title: The December 2019 Wax Headcone Discovery
part_1_2019_discovery.historical_mystery: For over a millennium of Egyptian art (3,550-2,000 years ago), cone-shaped objects appeared on people's heads in paintings, reliefs, and tomb decorations. No archaeologist had ever excavated one of the enigmatic objects, leading some scholars to think of Egyptian head cones as merely symbolic representations - the equivalent of the halos that appear on saints and angels in Christian iconography.

timeline.2010: First headcone discovered at Amarna on skull of woman aged 20-29 (Individual 150)

physical_analysis.primary_constituent: Biological wax (beeswax), not fat or incense
physical_analysis.structure: Hollow shells (not solid unguent as previously theorized)

spectroscopic_analysis.method: DRIFTS (Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy)

characteristic_peaks.720_730_cm: CH2 rotation in long carbon chains

part_1_2019_discovery.key_finding: The cones weren't solid - they were hollow shells folded around brown-black organic matter. Both head cones had chemical signatures of decayed wax; the team concluded they were made of beeswax.

significance.existence_confirmed: This discovery confirms that the cones did exist physically
significance.non_elite_access: Found in workers' cemeteries, not royal tombs, suggesting broader access to wax technology
significance.individual_150_details: Well-preserved hair with long, thick braids featuring many extensions and end-curls

part_1_2019_discovery.source: Stevens, A., Rogge, C.E., Bos, J.E.M.F., & Dabbs, G.R. (2019). 'From representation to reality: ancient Egyptian wax head cones from Amarna.' Antiquity, 93(372), 1515-1533.

part_4_punic_wax.title: Punic Wax and the Phoenician Connection
part_4_punic_wax.definition: Punic wax (Cera Punica) is saponified beeswax - beeswax treated with alkali to become water-soluble.
part_4_punic_wax.pliny_description: Beeswax boiled with seawater and natron (sodium carbonate), resulting in white, purified wax used for medicine, cosmetics, encaustic painting, and waterproofing.

sincere_etymology.folk_etymology: Roman sculptors allegedly filled cracks in marble statues with wax, then painted over them. 'Sine cera' (without wax) supposedly meant 'genuine, not fraudulent.'
